question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The only thing gained in this course was memorizable content. There was no development of skills, there was no development of engineering thought, the way the course was portrayed was as a memorize this style of teaching with fill in the blank notes. No design challenges were levied. there was little that was learned in this course that will help me going forward. I could have learned all of the specifics of each material in a job or a lab setting, and I was hoping that this being an engineering course could be based around thoughtful design, but it was strictly memorization of unimportant details. Three specific things that were memorized were hydrogels, composites, and metals. Based on the coursework alone, I would not be able to describe how each of these functions within a system or how to design a system around them.

response_text: This course could involve more things than simple regurgitation. Biomaterials is one of the biggest fields within BME, and it touches almost every other part of the academic area, so there are many design challenges that could be had with this course, but with the simple memorize and regurgitate style, the student is not stimulated. Design challenges, and in the homework asking students to build and consider why might one want to pick this biomaterial or structuring the course with the student in mind rather than checking off a box would make the course up to the Duke standard.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Figure creation: I learned how to think about and best present data from our experiments, which is not something I had done extensively before.
Problem solving: I improved my problem solving skills and ability to think outside of the box to form solutions. By being given broad questions and being allowed to think and reason for myself, I think I really developed an important skill of thinking more like a scientist.
Teamwork/collaboration: These labs were tough, but collaboration was encouraged. By talking through things with my classmates (as well as Dr. Bansal and Dr. Feeney), I learned so much more and was able to come up with good solutions and methods to analyze data and solve problems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned computational and analytical skills. Computationally I learned how to use statistics to evaluate data and answer scientific questions in a research study for example. Analytically, I learned how to use the concepts studied in class, and analyze different aspects of that concept but in a different setting. An example of this is, that I now know what would happens to the length of the sarcomere if calcium channels in the presynaptic terminal were faulty and couldn't let through calcium ions. This would ultimately prevent further propagation of the action potential across the synaptic cleft since the vesicles can't fuse to the presynaptic membrane. Ultimately, the length of the sarcomere wouldn't change.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Wallace is a good biology teacher but is not good at covering the other components of the course, of which there are many. His lectures are pretty solid and coming out of them you feel like you have a decent grasp of the biology component of the course. That being said, professor Wallace spends very little time on teaching the mathematical aspects of the course and the statistics component is poorly covered. Professor Wallace provides decent resources for self learning but the course is extremely difficult because of the amount of practice you have to do on your own in the math and statistics aspects. This course feels like three classes combined into one (biology, mathematics, and statistics) with only one taught very well and the other two lacking slightly.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Start the homework early, and do it on your own. You can check with others after you've finished, but you won't build problem solving intuition unless you work on the problem sets alone. When preparing for tests, don't overexert yourself doing practice problems. The main purpose of the problems is not to teach you new content but to train your intuition. If you start doing practice problems thinking that you have to do every single one in order to be prepared, you won't gain anything from doing them. Dr. Wallace mentions this before the first test, that a lot of students that don't do any problems still place among the top of the class on tests. For labs, start them early as possible and make sure you are proficient with both Python and MATLAB, especially knowing how to solve differential equations numerically and graph them.

Statistical Tests and when to apply them

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned many statistical tests, how electric signaling operates within the human body, and some models used in modern BME. Specifically, I learned stat-tests such as ANOVA, models such as Hodgkin-Huxley, and how physics can be applied to modern BME tools such as those used in a variety of imaging applciations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Statistical and physiological thinking in terms of anatomy and biology. Fully understanding anatomical processes and how changes in them affect the body.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Honestly everything that I wanted to be doing as a BME major. My courses up until now felt disconnected, and I understood that I should be taking these courses because they're "core engineering" classes, but I felt far away from my enjoyment of biology and physiology. I developed a lot more application-based skills over memorization, and I feel like I gained a lot of statistical analysis skills that can really aid me in the future. In fact, I was recently accepted for a summer program, and they told me a main reason why they chose me was because I demonstrated good understanding of biostatistical knowledge that could be applied in field research, and had mention this and BME244 in my application and interview.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I gained a deep understanding of how to quantitatively model physiological systems in the human body. I learned to model ion movement across cell membranes, including concepts like the action potential and the Hodgkin-Huxley model. I explored the different mechanisms behind skeletal and cardiac muscle contraction, as well as Hill’s model, which explains skeletal muscle behavior. The course also covered blood vessel mechanics, blood flow, microcirculation, and the renal system. Additionally, I developed proficiency in statistical methods such as t-tests, linear regression, and ANOVA.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Awesome class. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is extremely hard. The workload can get really crazy: some homework sets take 12 hours and some stats modules feel like they take 12 hours. (The stats modules are easily the worst part of this class, and I found them (while important) to be really exhausting and mind-numbing. Conceptually, if you are interested in physiology, the lectures will actually be sort of fun. Its not horrible to understand, but when you get stuck with homework, stats, and a lab in the same week, things can get really, really, dire.Also, I hope you have an I-pad, as without one you end up printing so so so much. I lug around about a whole ream of paper worth of printed lectures at all times, and I have actively spent an unfortunate amount of my personal money at the printer. If you were on the fence about getting an I-pad, it might genuinely be worth it for this class. You'd be fine without one though, I mean, I was :)All in all, this class is very rewarding. I feel like I have learned so much, and I feel pretty prepared for the future. And professor Wallace, while quite a difficult professor, is a really good instructor who will really help you to understand the stuff conceptually.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The questions and challenges posed in the problem themselves were very stimulating. I enjoyed the modelling process, and the actual projects yielded interesting explorations/results. This is perhaps a little bit unavoidable, but I feel like such large teams always yield in conflict as its difficult to delegate work efficiently. I think that we could've totally handled smaller groups of 3 individuals for this project, and it would've made it a lot easier since everyone would feel greater responsibility in the class.

-Take it with people you know, otherwise it'll be painful AND lonely
-You'll probably get an A, if you're premed and worried about your grade, it's just unnecessarily annoying

response_text: Libby is amazing. Hands down the best professor I have had at Duke. She is very engaging with the class and definitely makes sure that everyone is awake at 8:30 in the morning. Also, the way that she teaches with examples is so beneficial to my learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr Libby is one of the kindest professors I have had. She says she cares about her students but she really does things to make that true. She is always available after class to help and goes around the room to check for understanding, stopping at each student to explain anything we don’t grasp. Before exams she answers my individual list of questions with full detailed responses over an email. She even wrote personalized notes to us every so often in response to our feedback/get-to-know-you slides. I would keep all of this. She and the TAs were all great resources. The very frequent office hours with TAs were incredibly important for me to do my homeworks relatively painlessly, so I could focus on the concepts that mattered, work with other students, and get out of ruts faster when I got stumped on a problem.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about principalism in bioethics, I learned how to construct ethical arguments, I learned about elements of biotechnology and biomedical engineering I was not previously aware of.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to analyze biomedical technologies using ethical principles and language. I also learned about modern developments in controversial areas of biomedical engineering. Finally, I learned to effectively convey my ideas and support my points.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Ethical frameworks, Germline Genomic Editing, Brain Computer Interfaces

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned how to discuss ethical dilemmas within the biomedical field. The primary piece was creating a basis for how to discuss ethical issues through four key principles. We then focused on the fields of machine learning and artificial intelligence, organoids, gene editing, and brain-computer interfaces throughout the year.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Ethical and philosophical frameworks that govern biomedical ethics, and learning about the four technologies themselves too (gene editing, organoids, BCI, AI/ML)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I got more comfortable writing a long paper with context and argument. I heard ethical debates with regard to science that I hadn't considered before. I got better at articulating arguments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I deepened my understanding of bioethics beyond just the four bioethical principles. We talked extensively about autonomy, beneficence, non-maleficence, and justice. Every week, we talked the ethical implications as it related to different topics such as somatic and germline editing, BCIs, and stem cell research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I experienced a lot of development in my writing pertaining biomedical ethics. It's been a while, so this class really helped me with regards to writing longer essay assignments and making sure I incorporated sources with purpose. I also gained a lot of insight on the current standing of up-and-coming biomedical technologies as well as ethical concerns that we need to address in our pursuit of such technologies. Overall, the course was extremely helpful and I find myself thinking about the ethics of BME in my spare time often.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- ethical and moral frameworks
- applying frameworks to specific case studies including CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing, brain computer interfaces
- writing argumentative and perspectives essays
- writing short reflection papers based on course content

response_text: If you are an engineer coming into this course, be prepared for heavy amounts of reading and writing. The readings can range from dense technical information about how technologies you will discuss in class to ethical arguments about such technologies. The ethics-focused readings, while still equally dense at times, are usually still interesting as they tackle opinions on the use of the technologies. There's also a substantial writing portion to the class. This consists of ~400-word recaps every other week related to what you discussed in class to two ~4000-word essays right before spring break and then the week before LDOC.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

That being said it definitely is a tough class, and since there are only 4 homework assignments throughout the year, you'll need to make sure to start early so that you or your friends have time to ask questions in office hours.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Fundamentals of Imaging Modalities: I learned the basic physics and engineering principles behind major imaging systems like MRI, CT, ultrasound, and X-ray, and how each one is suited for different diagnostic needs.
Image Formation and Reconstruction: I gained insight into how raw data is collected and mathematically processed to create detailed medical images, including concepts like Fourier transforms and filtering.
Critical Evaluation of Imaging Systems: I developed the ability to think critically about imaging quality, safety , and system limitations when choosing the best imaging method for a given clinical situation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about the methodologies behind various medical imaging modalities, including x-ray projection radiography, CT scanning, ultrasonography, MRIs, and nuclear medicine. 
I learned how to balance the tradeoffs between signal to noise ratios with other necessary considerations including patient comfort, time, and costs associated with scanning. 
I developed certain coding skills -- using Python and Matlab to model the mathematics behind imaging systems.

response_text:
Learned lots of different cellular engineer techniques, which were supplemented with what we did in lab. 
1. learned a lot about cellular delivery mechanisms, notably viral vectors 
2. learned a good amount about the extracellular environment and the way that it interfaces with cells

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The content of this course was very interesting and engaging. I loved learning about cellular physiology, and I felt like this class contained a great amount of depth about things that we mostly just glossed over in Bio 201. I feel much more equipped to do research at the scale of cellular/tissue engineering, and I think this course expanded my knowledge base in a way that will allow me to make connections and come up with ideas in areas I wouldn't have thought of before. We learned a lot about gene regulation, protein production, cell proliferation/growth/death, metabolism, cell signaling, adhesion, migration, the ECM, and cell therapies. Everything connected together well and was framed through an engineering lens.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot because of this course; the labs especially taught me so much and I am so grateful for that. The labs are really the crux of the course, and the information we gain in lecture is also quite amazing. I learned PCR, Western Blotting, and numerous other lab techniques. I also learned much about cell differentiation and how important the cellular microenviornment really is.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Content wise I learnt about CAR T cell therapies, the central dogma in detail, gene regulation by modifying distinct steps within the central dogma, cell adhesion, the environmental factors and forces affecting cells... I applied team learning skills and improved problem solving skills. I also reviews novel papers and learnt about true cellular engineering applications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned different gene therapy methods. I learned how to change the cells microenvironment to change the output. I learned how to create stem cells and their uses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned what computational fluid dynamics is and methods to analyze fluid flow, I learned that there are often significant limitations in peer-reviewed, published scientific articles, and how to dissect a very dense journal article.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to really take engineering problems from the floor to the roof. In the sense that we could take problems from just problem statements and turn them into project/paper level problems. We were able to do this because of our solid understanding of the material.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course, I’ve learned many different methods for examining fluid and molecular transport in the body, including how to reduce more complex models (for example, Navier-Stokes reduction methods) and when we can apply certain models (semi-infinite media assumptions, entrance lengths, vessel curvature, etc.). I’ve learned how to analyze different kinds of fluid flow and diffusion throughout the body and apply the models we’ve learned to more complex computational setups (using flow as a diagnostic, for example). Additionally I’ve been exposed to methods in computational fluid dynamics both through the paper discussions and through the computer projects, which showed me what kinds of computational setups are possible — and how what we learn in class can be applied in the real world to help diagnose and treat patients.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Understanding of mass transport processes across different physiological systems.
Mathematical modeling of fluid flow.
Understanding of the complexities of convection and diffusion.
Using CFD visualization software and interpreting the context of outputted results.
Understanding the most recent, cutting-edge literature related to fluid dynamics

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
BME 307 provided an excellent combination of physiology and engineering. What I enjoyed most was truly seeing the clinical applications of class material, through computer projects such as designing a shunt to avoid wall shear stress. I gained skills in mathematical computation, putting math in the context of the body, and brainstorming methods to use equations in ways I hadn't previously used them. Three specific things I learned are: 
1. Every patient is unique, down the deformability of their blood cells. This may seem obvious, but simply learning about hematocrit levels and understanding how even a slight variation in hematocrit can result in drastic changes in blood fluid mechanics was impactful. When it comes to patient care, the individual patient must be treated as such, taking into account the geometry of their unique vessels and the properties of their blood. 
2. Mathematical analysis can be infinitely complicated; in clinical settings, it is sometimes acceptable to make simplifications/assumptions to simplify computation, but it is very important to understand where these assumptions come from and when they are valid.
3. I learned the impact that computational visualizations have on the field of medicine and healthcare. Physicians can not make very important decisions without the correct tools to visualize their surgical plans and apply these plans to individual patients.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I was a big fan of the paper reviews and presentations, I thought they were a nice way to see real-life applications of the stuff we learn in lectures, and allowed the topics to sit more concretely in my mind. I also really liked the format for the homework and quizzes, where we had homework quizzes. I think a lot of times in other classes, if we just have homework, we kind of j slave thru it j for the sake of having it done to turn in and get a grade for it and don't thinl too much when there is small stuff confusing us. But on the homework for our class, if there was even one line of math that didn't make sense, I would always take the time to fully understand it because it could show up on the quiz.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Overall, I think that the layout of the course was very helpful — having time to think about concepts we learned in class when doing the homework was very nice, since those assignments were more spaced out. Additionally, I think the paper discussions and computer projects were incredibly valuable because they helped connect concepts in the classroom to possible areas for further exploration.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
I really enjoyed how Dr. Randles made sure to incorporate real-world applications into the course throughout the lessons. Often times, in some other BME classes, the content has felt "dry" because students are not able to understand how they can apply the knowledge.
Instead of going into the details of every step of a mathematical derivation, we understood the high-level concepts that we can take away as we move on to the next phases of our careers.
Finally, I enjoyed having a chance to write the abstracts and have classwide discussions of the literature papers. It was super helpful to understand how the equations we are learning in class are used in research and what steps remain until these technologies can be used in a clinical setting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Randles and Nusrat did an excellent job of instructing the course, especially in terms of providing help with homework problems and creating an interactive learning environment. Dr. Randles is personable and cares about our understanding. I enjoyed that she often gave examples of real-world situations to put our class material in a greater context. I enjoyed homework quizzes; they ensured that we could not only complete the homework but could reproduce it on any given day. Additionally, the computer projects were helpful in showing the significance of this course material.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Application of knowledge - nothing in this course was simple memorization or plug and chug formulas. Every single problem taught me to deeply consider what I was being asked and the entire situation at hand before thinking about how to tackle it - a valuable critical thinking skill to have I think.
Team problem solving - this was a very team heavy class, as we spent every class period solving problems in our groups. I think I got better at learning everyone's strengths and weaknesses and working as a team very effectively to solve extremely difficult problems.
COMSOL - I had never used COMSOL and now feel fairly comfortable and familiar with it. This is a skill that I think will serve me very well in the future and is valuable to have.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Perhaps most importantly though, I learned more about the electrical and mechanical system of the heart and how pacemakers work to stimulate cardiac tissue.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three big things I learned are:Using circuits to model biological systems: I learned how to take things like heart activity and represent them with simple electrical circuits, like RC circuits.How to capture and clean up biological signals: I got hands-on experience with how devices pick up signals like ECGs, and how important it is to deal with noise. I learned about different techniques, like filtering, to make sure the signals we record are actually useful.Blending biology and engineering to solve problems: This course taught me how to think across disciplines — not just focusing on the biology or the electronics by themselves, but learning how to combine both sides when designing medical devices like sensors or monitors.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is really informative and I enjoyed it thoroughly, despite being anxious to take it. The teacher is very approachable and makes sure to meet students where they are at in terms of their understanding level (he never makes people feel bad for not understanding a topic whether it should have been learned in a previous class or earlier in this class). The labs take the full three hours each week, but none of the tasks are busywork and everything really builds on itself. There is a lot of pride at the end of the semester when you and your partner have built up a fully functioning pacemaker for a frog. The midterm practical can be stressful, but make sure to use the lab hours and be calm/confident. Overall, BME 354 was one of the more fun engineering classes I have taken so far at Duke.

course: BME-390L-001 : SPECIAL TOPICS WITH A LAB.BME-390L-001.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In molecular engineering, I learned both a fascinating suite of wet and dry lab tools to develop small molecules and proteins. Specifically, I learned how to visualize proteins in 3D space with PyMol, relax them using Rosetta, fold them using AlphaFold, and make new ones with RFDiffusion. In addition, the wet lab taught me how to design a protein, order a Twist fragment, perform Gibson assembly, express the protein, analyze it, and purify it.

response_text: 1) I learned about career paths in the biotech industry from the course's field trips that were really insightful. 2) I learned about the path and process to FDA regulatory approval for biotech, which hasn't been something that I've learned in classes thus far and was valuable to get exposure to. 3) I got to perform the DBTL cycle in lab on our AAV design.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Excellent class! I learned a lot from each component of the class including the lab, lectures, guest speakers, and field trips! Super valuable class to take as a BME senior. In lab, I learned about the whole process of making AAV, transducing it into cells, and testing it. It was very useful to learn new techniques and review ones that I've practiced in previous classes. I learned about the whole bench-to-bedside process of drug development and so much about GMP, process development, manufacturing and scaling up, translation from lab to companies, novel biotechnologies, bioethics, and scientific communication!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Organized lots of opportunities to talk and learn from folks in industry. I also appreciated the work setup by the instructor and TAs to facilitate a smooth learning lab environment, designing protocols and preparing things for us in lab. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Kim is a great instructor and I think this course is really well-designed and taught. His lectures get into the bigger picture of biotech, which feels like an excellent capstone to all the more granular classes I've taken. He went through the whole bench-to-bedside process of drug development while also supplementing with interesting guest speakers and field trips to a GMP facility and the cellular processing development facility. He also talked about bioethics a lot, as well as just general career and life advice for moving forward in biotech. I feel like this prepared me very well to be a leader in the field in the future. Dr. Kim clearly cares so much about our development as scientists and people, and I feel like he cares a lot that we leave Duke BME armed with both technical skills and human-centered practices. In class, and especially in lab, he facilitates a low-pressure and friendly learning environment where everyone is comfortable being confused and asking questions, which has helped me learn SO much over my years working in the teaching lab. He also gives good feedback on design pitches and proposals.Shoutout also to the teaching lab staff. Maggie and Melanie (and Matt and Lizzie, although they weren't involved with this class) are SUCH a huge asset to the department. They know everything and are so willing to help. They put in so much work to make every course and lab experience run smoothly, and I would absolutely tell younger BMEs to chat with them and become friendly with them, because they are wonderful and kind people, and utilizing their help absolutely has made my Duke BME experience smoother!!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a lot of fun! Highly recommend.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Lab is useful for getting hands on experience. The group for lab and group for proposals are such a large part of the course that it is too risky to take it unless you know who you will group with already and are guaranteed to be able to choose your own groups. They persist for an entire academic year so it is imperative to get a good group.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great class! Well-run and not too much work outside of class. Aside from the three big group assignments of the long design proposals, the other outside work was just pre-lab quizzes, easy lab reports, and the occasional pre-lecture assignment. Lab is cool and doesn't usually take the full 3 hours. It's cool to hear guest speakers and take field trips, and you'll learn a lot about commercializing biotech products. Feels like a very Duke BME class in the sense that it's really preparing you to be a leader in biotech and think about the big picture, not just granular details. Working with Master's students is also cool. Dr. Kim is a great mentor so definitely be willing to chat with him.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Get started on project proposals early and go through the feedback on each one and you'll do well. Also don't forget pre-lecture/prelab assignments.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a good course to take if interested in biotech design, industry and academic pathways. It dives deeper into a wide range of topics, and prepares you for either industry or academia. Very useful, be ready to work in many group projects.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dr. Kim knows what he's talking about. You'll get as much out of this class as you put in, and this prepares you very well for going into biotech. Take it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will enjoy it

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you have a strong interest in biotechnology, this class provides alot of insight into the current state of this facet of biomedical engineering and you are afforded the opportunity to propose innovative ideas within this space as a part of your projects.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Start brainstorming ideas for your proposals early just because that's the one part you can't rush and it's so much more motivating if you're working on a proposal (and eventually project) you think is really cool. Also you get what you want to from the prelabs and readings, so intentionally decide what content you want to read (a lot of it is useful).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Any student considering a career in biotech, whether in academia or industry, should take this course to learn every aspect of a scientist's experience.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the open-ended nature of the course as it allows teams to explore topics of their interest. I also think the course simulates the environment of a biotech company which is a beneficial perspective for students that are seeking a job in industry.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors were readily available both in person and over online communication platforms such as slack to answer any questions or concerns. Additionally weekly meetings also helped facilitate greater understanding of our project and allowed us to overcome any obstacles we were encountered.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked the weekly meetings with professors and that it was mostly independent lab work with check-ins. I thought the memos were a good way to keep us on track, and that the intermediate deadlines for writing the manuscript were good! Also the whole structure of the teaching lab is great and I love having all the resources available + super helpful staff! Some of the lectures were good, and I especially liked the ones about making good figures and posters, and the guest speaker about VC.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It is exciting to work on your own biotech project and carry out every step of the process.

response_text: - Endless opportunities and resources to do our own project and investigate what our group wants

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Troubleshooting was very intellectually stimulating as it required my team to come up with new ways to clone DNA and test things. I think this is the single most important skill I will gain after taking this class. The guest lectures were quite inspiring too. I loved the guest lecture with a VC representative as it provided perspectives on the types of companies private funds are interested in.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The fact that we were required to come up with ideas on our own and test them in the lab independently especially made this class intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I liked the project portion a lot but I'm sure you guys know that the lecture portion could use some work. I would have enjoyed more bioethics integration– case studies rather than the super broad overview. Possibly another thing could be setting aside 15-20 mins of each class for teams to meet with each other, because this happened informally for my team during class anyways (sometimes just by texting each other while sitting at the same table). Also a more community-focused aim of the class where we have check-ins about future plans and things like that. I feel like this class was good for building community across the 2 semesters, but there could be even more of that! Or maybe let students give 3-5 minute talks about their research outside of class if they do it! I'd love to hear what other people in the class work on independently.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class is very lab-heavy and can be time consuming. Towards the end of the semester we each went into lab at least once or twice every week for over 3 hours.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great course if interested in biotech and potentially want to go into graduate school (highly recommend if you are!). You learn so much carrying out your own project and build great teamwork skills and responsibilities. You definitely need to be proactive and care about your project. You get out as much as you want and can put in to the project. You learn that science is hard, but it can be very rewarding.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I liked the project portion a lot but I'm sure you guys know that the lecture portion could use some work. I would have enjoyed more bioethics integration– case studies rather than the super broad overview. Possibly another thing could be setting aside 15-20 mins of each class for teams to meet with each other, because this happened informally for my team during class anyways (sometimes just by texting each other while sitting at the same table). Also a more community-focused aim of the class where we have check-ins about future plans and things like that. I feel like this class was good for building community across the 2 semesters, but there could be even more of that! Or maybe let students give 3-5 minute talks about their research outside of class if they do it! I'd love to hear what other people in the class work on independently.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel like I didn’t learn anything and I’m genuinely upset about it. The class seemed to only reiterate everything we learned in EGR101- how to write need statements, how to define and use functional requirements, identifying and describing the roles of stakeholders, conducting screening and scoring, or how to give presentations. Assignments were applying concepts I already knew to a different problem. I did learn things about my specific design problem. But I didn’t learn anything about the engineering process.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more in-depth knowledge about the product development lifecycle. I learned about all of the research and documentation that is required when developing a new medical device. I learned about the importance of stakeholder interviews and market reserach to ensure that a medical device has an attainable market size to ensure its success.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I didn't learn anything from this course. This class felt like EGR101 reimagined, without acquiring skills through the tools mastery portion. It's amazing to me how poor this class was run, with the initial weeks forcing students to think of an unsolved problem in the BME space to create a solution within less than a year. These unsolved problems require more extensive backgrounds of electrical and mechanical systems to better propose solutions that could be implemented. We don't need to go through Pugh scoring matrices and create 50 ideas, 45 of which are just to submit the assignment. There's also no need to spend weeks on creating a narrative and ensuring that the problem we propose to tackle is valid. This course was just self driven, so you gained stuff from what you put into it. So personally, I learned a lot as I wanted to go down a specific pathway, however, Dr. Kyle made it clear that this method wouldn't work out and that we should scrap it, after we informed him (and he agreed) that we could continue on this path. Frustrating for sure, but not a conducive environment for learning and developing new skills. Not only that, but when wanting to apply to engineering jobs next semester, it would've been super helpful to develop some skills. However, when Dr. Kyle constantly bats everything down and constantly gives us negative feedback with no positive remarks, it leads you to be unmotivated and disinterested in the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: There are numerous significant problems with BME 473 that I will enumerate throughout my course evaluation, and I trust that my word will be taken seriously.Truthfully, I did not develop any new skills, insights, or ways of thinking in BME 473. Most of the lecture time was spent teaching the foundations of the Engineering Design Process, which is a fundamental framework that I internalized in EGR 101 - the first engineering course I took at Duke. Before starting BME 473, I had already learned how to define a problem, formulate a need statement, outline stakeholders, explain functional requirements, understand constraints, build a proof of principle, screen solution ideas, construct scoring matrices for quantitative decision-making, and deliver effective presentations. We spent excessive time reviewing these basic engineering topics in the class, which subtracted from time that could be spent working towards a solution. I genuinely do not understand the need for such a comprehensive review of EGR 101 topics, and the result of this wasted time will be evident in the fidelity of every group's final project. In fact, Dr. Kyle has recommended targeting a low or medium fidelity prototype as the final product. This indicates that our EGR 101 final products and our BME 473 final products will roughly have the same fidelity, which is concerning given the difference in principle between those two courses.Naturally, this course has felt like a waste of time. I will say that I gained new knowledge, but this is only due to research conducted on our specific design problem. Given that any design course would entail such research, I think it is fair to conclude that BME 473 offers almost no unique benefits as a course; it only facilitates a design project, and it even accomplishes that poorly. In reality, the course structure of BME 473 has simply taught me to diminish my expectations for the "senior design" experience.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Dr. Kyle was very accessible via Slack and responsive. He would be open to meet outside of class time and was happy to provide feedback while groups were in the process of completing an assignment.
Groups were challenged to push themselves outside their comfort zone and coordinate stakeholder interviews outside of class time. Expectations and assignment details were clear for the most part.
Design review meetings were held leading up to the midterm and final presentation dates. 
The pre-recorded lecture videos helped students to become familiar with material prior to attending class. 
I appreciate Dr. Kyle's energy that he brings to the classroom. It is easy to tell how passionate he is about teaching medical device design.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: this class provided me with the opportunity to finally dedicate time to my own medical device, alongside my teammates. I liked learning more about medical device product development. the IP lecture was stimulating and interesting. i also appreciated clear rubrics for the assignments. i thought the video lectures were great and preferred those so that we could maximize group work time during lectures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: No learning was facilitated. I was unmotivated to learn because of the negative feedback on every assignment. You'd have one positive conversation with a clear path to victory, and weeks later, it is thwarted with Dr. Kyle not believing in the method you proposed. To go through an entire two-month period with little to no communication from Dr. Kyle and then end the final presentation with not a single positive comment is pretty unfortunate. I like to think of learning being facilitated by your ability to be an effective professor who guides your students toward a problem and ensures that they are not only meeting all of the goals you set up in the semester but also that they are learning along the way. Dr. Kyle did neither. Not only this, lecture time was supposed to be dedicated towards working to idea research or to devise solutions. Instead, Dr. Kyle lectured about everything in EGR101! This class was a prerequisite for all of engineering! It isn't necessary to reiterate this, mostly because of the inability to cover all of this within a short enough fashion to still allow for a fully fleshed out solution to be created. I think the whole idea of trying to stimulate our minds to be better entrepreneurs, and instead of devising the technologies we should attempt to find a problem first is an amazing concept to be learned, but in graduate school. I think for the undergrads, its more important to hone in on the soft skills, such as CAD, ECAD, circuit design, electrical testing, and firmware development to be able to go into an engineering job and tackle whatever project assigned on the first day. If I'm prompted to instead research potential solutions, and then whenever I come up with said articles to share it immediately gets batted down, it leads to an environment that nobody can thrive in.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Kyle is a nice person, so it may be difficult to believe that his course is significantly flawed. However, I assure you that this course needs to be heavily restructured. I think the plan of developing a Design History File and delivering presentations to share progress is an important part of this course, so I would not change that. That being said, a certain scrutiny must be applied to other components of the course; there are numerous flaws in the idea generation process, the design review meetings, and the balance between work input and reward output. I will elaborate on these in the sections that ask about course improvement.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: So much of this semester was dedicated to re-learning concepts from EGR101. I get it; they are necessary to the design engineering process, and we must understand them. However, it is also the most tedious part of engineering when it is drawn out over months without any tangible exercises or hands-on application. I felt that by having us complete extensive assignments on it, I was either stretched thin to complete a little bit of everything on a project assignment or worked on writing 6 pages on one part of the assignment and never got the big picture learning of the entire design process. I think there are ways we can limit the amount of lecture time in class, and increase the amount of group project work time with individual check-ins from more professional engineers beyond Dr. Kyle - we would have loved to bounce one-off questions and ideate with other people like TAs or lab managers like Matt Brown who can offer their expertise as well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: focus on process rather than innovation

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class could be more intellectually stimulating if almost anything was done differently. 1. "flipped classroom" model has been watching 4 lectures outside of class to be given the final 15 minutes of class to work on something unrelated to our teams progress. If you're going to design this course as a flipped classroom model, lean into it. 2. start the class by giving us some mini-project assignments to introduce us to some skills and technologies that typical design projects may use. what has ended up happening is that people who like coding have given themselves coding projects, people who like CAD have given themselves CAD projects, and people who like circuits have given themselves circuitry projects. Nobody is developing any skills. 3. reward hard work... this is the only class I've taken where the professor keeps moving the goalposts. we've asked for Dr. Kyle's feedback both before and after assignments. somehow, his feedback always changes. one day he'll tell us to move forward with something and then next day he'll tell us that was a bad idea.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Mentioned in the above question.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The back end of the class was very disapointing and I felt like proof of principle testing really impacted how positively I viewed the class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class has been fairly similarly structured to EGR 101, which is not a bad thing because that was a great class but it did feel repetitive at times. A significant bit of lecture time was taken up by topics that have been covered in short pre-recorded videos. One thing that I found made this class stimulating was bringing in outside speakers to discuss their problems, but that only happened once. While those projects did not interest my group, it's quite possible that others might have. In a course where many of the problems are student-defined, it's difficult to find an actual need that hasn't already been solved, but can also be accomplished within the time constraints of this sequence. More problems being presented could have helped that.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class would be far more intellectually stimulating if it explored principles related to medical device design. Topics such as PCB design, signal processing, different types of microcontrollers, or other electrical engineering topics would have been much more stimulating. As a BME senior design course, it should involve teaching how to integrate the knowledge I have gained from my previous BME courses into a complete design. It should not be a rehashing of EGR 101, but limited even further by the narrow scope of allowed projects. More time to prototype would have been appreciated. I would like to point out that the course is designated as an IM (medical imaging) area elective, even though nothing taught in the course was related to medical imaging.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Problems should be outlined by the professor at the beginning of the class. This class should be centered around actually designing something physical, not around seeing a product through from the first steps of needs finding and value propositions. I would be 1000x happier with this class if I were walking away with something that I had built this semester.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I see a lot of the BME classes as background knowledge, like physics or chemistry, and expect a class like this to teach how to leverage this knowledge to create a device. I expected this class to teach me how to identify a problem. I expected this class to teach me how to thoroughly and methodically design something to solve a problem. Neither of these happened. While I wish I learned engineering concepts, the class still would have been stimulating had it been on a problem that mattered to me. But once again, we weren’t provided with the tools for idea generation or filtering. Student-proposed ideas seemed to be put down.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
It was rewarding having the opportunity to be able to apply and integrate knowledge from multiple past classes.
I liked how we devoted a substantial chunk of the first half of the semester to design research. It was critical to have an understanding of the disease statement fundamentals as well as an overview of the existing treatments in the market.
Designing our own PoP testing plan was also quite challenging, and required students to stay organized when compiling information from the literature.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I felt instructor support from a technical standpoint was lacking this semester. I found myself not receiving helpful or actionable feedback from instructors on how to go about developing or testing potential solutions beyond combing through the literature. I feel that one thing that could really improve the student experience for next semester would be to have enough TAs such that one TA could be assigned to each student group. At this point, we know there are 8 student teams, and we know what problem they are working on. Thus, it would be extremely helpful to have a TA with background knowledge relevant to the problem who can provide technical assistance to teams on an individual basis, this would allow for teams to get feedback during every class session: during this semester, Dr. Kyle would go around talking with teams, but there would not be enough time for him to catch up with all teams during class. Thus, I think this change could improve engagement with the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really wanted to gain technical skills while creating our device, and that is something that has been lacking thus far. We've done more writing and planning and preparation than actual building, and for a design class I wish it was the other way around.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think more enthusiasm and positive attitude in the classroom environment would make the class more stimulating. I also think more group autonomy over the projects, with supportive mentorship from the instructors would be ideal.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: My brain probably smoothed from lecture. It was only intellectually stimulating when we opted to go down the path that Dr. Kyle and us agreed upon, only for it to lead to him saying that we shouldn't go down this path anymore. Other than that, it was everything I hated from EGR101 on steroids and with considerably more subjective grading. There are some 'sunshine' projects in the class that seem to be doing much better because they're able to make more tangible progress throughout the semester while you have other groups screening for cancer!?!?! How is the grading supposed to be consistent throughout all of the different groups, especially when you first have to verify your every move with Dr. Kyle? There is no room for creative freedom in this course, and I understand that Dr. Kyle can't just let us go down a rabbit hole of complete nonsense, but if it's for the greater good of us to understand the engineering design process and develop new skills, why wouldn't we opt to have a structure that is a little looser? By constantly going back and forth with Dr. Kyle, you lose a lot of this intellectual stimulation because you're instead choosing to do the thing that will earn you a better grade in the course instead of learning.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
This class was not intellectually stimulating - let me lay out some further complaints with the specific class structure (really an extension of the previous question).3. Dr. Kyle's grading policies are ambiguous to the point where they are unhelpful. Additionally, individual assignment grades are locked to 85%, 90%, or 97%, which is a practice I have never seen before.A big issue with BME 473 is the ambiguity of the grading guidelines. For each assignment, Dr. Kyle publishes a set of guidelines for achieving an LP, P, or HP grade. Though I would normally refer to this as a rubric, Dr. Kyle has specified that these guidelines are not rubrics. Frequently, there is no explicit distinction between the P and HP guidelines; that choice is entirely up to Dr. Kyle. Although Dr. Kyle is aware about this ambiguity, it seems to be a point of pride in the course structure rather than an issue in his eyes. This lack of clarity has consequences on the assignment grades, but the implications stretch beyond just the grade. For example, two groups with different interpretations of assignment guidelines may put entirely different levels of effort towards an assignment. Yet, they emerge with the same grade for both assignments, and this has happened repeatedly. This clearly demonstrates a bad return on investment for the group that worked harder on the assignment. In my opinion, such inconsistencies are a sign of a poorly constructed grading policy.4. The workload in this class is not justifiable given the slow pace of solution development.I believe BME 473 has exhibited the lowest return on investment of any BME class I’ve taken. Many weeks, our group is tasked with writing up 30-40 page documents (which seems to usually be skimmed), yet only a small fraction of this information has been relevant in our final project. The hefty workload of the original design research assignments was understandably an intentionally structured component of the course, and I acknowledge the value in establishing a wide breadth of design research. However, this philosophy did not cooperate well with Dr. Kyle’s tendency to oppose students’ ideas. The result was that we did excessive amounts of research, yet Dr. Kyle invalidated most of it after skimming our homework assignments in minutes. It would have been far more beneficial to everyone if we could have filtered these ideas before writing pages of research on them.
 
I do not think grading should be controlled by one single authority. The subjectivity that has governed the grading system of this class should not be in the hands of one person, especially with all the issues I've posed with BME 473. Maybe it would be helpful to loop Matt Brown in on grading, as he is a consultant for the course.I think serious attention should be paid to student-professor interactions in this course. Most of my negative attitude towards this class has spawned from my interactions with the professor. I don't want to recommend any specific changes in this area, but I strongly believe that the BME department owes its students an improved senior design course.The solution development phase of this course needs to begin much sooner into the semester. In general, the pace of this course was too slow to warrant its heavy workload, as it genuinely feels like we have worked very hard for a very insignificant outcome. The past few weeks have been the most interesting segment of the course, as we were actually allowed to build and test prototypes for our prospective solutions. That proof of principle segment should be a much greater emphasis in BME 473.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is not the creative design experience you are expecting. While you do learn how to approach a medical problem, the course structure is inflexible and intransparent more often than not. Not a great senior capstone experience overall.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready for a lot of reading and writing. Also, make sure your weekly assignments are completed in good detail; it will help you down the line for your midterm and final projects.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I was really excited to take this class. I'd been looking forward to it since sophomore year. Now, I would advise underclassmen to avoid taking this class. It is loaded with busy-work, and I feel I have not developed any technical skills. We spend way too much time writing and way too little time working on building technical skills.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I was the most excited about this class my senior year, and now between the first and second semester of the course, I strongly considered dropping the class to take another design elective instead. While the concept of designing a medical device over the course of the whole year is quite enticing, I don't think the class is designed in a way to encourage your success in a positive, uplifting way where you learn and grow as an engineer in this last year. It's sadly been a point of frustration this whole semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I had high hopes for this class, but at this time, I would not recommend it to another student.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The concept for this class is an excellent idea, a two-semester sequence that would ideally give students interested in device design more time to fully flesh out and complete their design for a device that solves a real problem. However, I would manage my expectations if this course is run the same way in the future. A significant portion of the first semester is taken up by problem research, which while interesting, does take a lot of time away from the actual design process. If tweaked slightly, this course could be an incredible and rewarding experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend they take a different senior design course. They would likely learn more in a different course. On a more emotional aspect, I feel that a senior design course should instill some sense of accomplishment in the student as they wrap up their undergraduate career, and this class feels weighed down by its numerous requirements and assignments, leaving little room for achieving anything satisfactory. I will note that this course is a two-semester sequence; therefore, the next semester may be more interesting. However, I would tell my peers that the slog through the first semester is not worth their time when they could be taking other courses that teach far more.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Take advantage of another capstone where you will actually make something and learn skills that you will use in the future.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do not take this class. I don’t know a single person that doesn’t regret taking it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would not recommend pursuing this 2-semester design sequence to future students. Entering this course, I thought that having an extra semester for the design project would result in stronger prototyping and testing and would result in a project much more technically sound than the projects in EGR 101. However, most of this first semester has been spent on written assignments, thus pushing nearly all the hands-on prototyping to the second semester. Thus, I don’t feel there is a significant benefit to pursuing this 2-semester sequence over a 1-semester design class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If future iterations of this course give more time to actual designing/prototyping, take this course. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Work hard on the deliverables, pay attention to details

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you want to validate everything you do constantly and are not left with academic freedom, this class is for you. If you, instead, are the type of person who yearns for academic stimulation by independently embarking on random intellectual tangents, don't take this class. Be prepared to earn passes or low passes on your assignments because the high passes are for the overachievers who have no other commitments. If you hated EGR101, be prepared to make it double. If you went in hoping that it would be a fun experience where you get to enjoy solving a problem and devising a solution by developing your soft skills throughout the process, I challenge you to think again. Attendance is required, and it isn't because you get to do work in classtime. It is required because you get to discuss stuff that isn't your problem, and you get to learn about how to do research and write up certain things you've already covered in every BME class you've taken beforehand.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I strongly recommend that you do not take the year-long senior design sequence. The one-semester alternative will push you harder, but you will be far more intellectually stimulated, and you will learn to value your ability as an engineer. I cannot say the same about BME 473.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Design Iteration and Prototyping: I learned how important it is to quickly build, test, and refine prototypes based on real feedback, rather than trying to perfect the design in one step.Regulatory and Risk Analysis: I gained skills in identifying potential risks in device design and understanding how to address them according to FDA guidelines and industry standards.Team-Based Project Management: I learned how to work more effectively in a multidisciplinary team, balancing technical work with communication, documentation, and meeting project deadlines — skills that are critical for real-world engineering.

response_text: I appreciated the various days spent on prototyping where we could seek out as much assistance as we needed from the TA or professor, or just stick to working on our own.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Kyle gave us a lot of room to work on things ourselves, but he also was always willing to provide help or support when we wanted it. I really enjoyed having all of our classes in a lab space so that we could be efficient with our time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
