question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Kyle was deeply invested in each of our design teams. I felt that the timing and spacing of progress reports, and design review meetings every other week was good. I felt well supported and the check-ins were helpful to keep us on track.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Kyle is always walking around the lab room to make sure that all teams are doing well and helping anyone who needs help. He is always very aware of what each person/team is working on so he is super helpful in debugging problems and bouncing ideas. One component of the course that I found very useful is the design review meetings, as it gave us a chance to catch up with Dr. Kyle on issues and topics that perhaps we wouldn't have brought up when he walks around lab. Furthermore, the DHFs while time-intensive really helped us take a deeper dive into topics like competitor analysis, regulatory processes, etc., which then helped us make more informed decisions for our design.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked having regular design review meetings with the instructors, and I also liked having the open lab where we could go in and work whenever we required.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr.Kyle really supported our learning by giving us a lot of freedom to explore our own designs while still providing clear guidance when we needed it. Having regular design reviews and check-ins helped keep our projects on track without feeling micromanaged. I would definitely keep the open-ended project structure and the regular feedback sessions for future years — they made the class feel a lot more like real-world engineering.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This course was particularly stimulating because I came in with a vision that would mean that I got to use skills I learned in other courses and bring them to life. This ended up being my biggest contribution to the overall project I still take pride in.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I felt that it was very rewarding to start with a problem completely from the start, and slowly build our progress, research, documentation, solutions all the way into testing. There was always a new step where we'd learn something new, there was always different problems that would come up to troubleshoot.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The problems presented to us by doctors and nurses at the start of the year were very interesting and definitely more complex than what I've heard from other design courses, so our projects were very engaging and fun to work on.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Having the freedom to design and go in any direction we wanted, with support from the professor, was very stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because we got to take real ownership of our projects and creatively solve problems like actual engineers.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! One huge things I've always sought was hands-on coursework and this course fulfilled that criteria ten times over.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely suggest taking the course! Dr. Kyle is an amazing professor who truly loves helping students in any way he can. The class really made me enjoy the design process more and I enjoyed having a project we worked on for multiple semesters because we were able to produce something I was very happy with.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It definitely takes a lot of time particularly the last few weeks to be able to create a successful design. But it is very rewarding to be able to complete and accomplish that.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class! I felt like it was a good culmination of my BME experience at Duke -- I feel like a one semester design course is not enough time to go much beyond the scope of like an EGR101 project. Dr. Kyle is a great instructor, and truly cares about all of his students and wants you to succeed. He was very responsive to feedback, and would check-in, sometimes adjusting assignments/deadlines as needed. If you are interested in pursuing industry within medical devices, definitely take this class. You learn relevant things and Dr. Kyle also brought in some guest speakers for us. Also, he has a fire taste in music and has excellent tunes going during work sessions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it. The two semester design course is so much more stimulating than a one semester version and you will be able to tackle more complex problems and learn more skills. Dr. Kyle does a great job of teaching this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class! You are given so much freedom to explore and design what you'd like to with a lot of support. There is lots of hands-on work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take the time outside of class to use office hours, and go into the lab.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Going through the final project too helped greatly illuminate all of the various components that must be considered when trying to get a product to market.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The electrophysical, conduction, and pacemaking system of the heart, understanding the heart as an electrical system. The circulatory system of the body and modeling the system as a circuit. The current and future therapies for various cardiac pathologies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed an in-depth knowledge of the structure and function of the heart and cardiovascular system as a whole, all the way from the cell level to the overall tissue/organ level. This course taught me common methods for modeling electrical function in cardiac cells (Hodgkin-Huxley model, cable model, etc.) and for modeling blood flow through vessels with compliance and resistance (Windkessel model). This course also taught me a lot about different treatments methods and therapies which helped me gained insight into common strategies for cell therapy and tissue engineering.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have developed a thorough and high knowledge on the cardiovascular system, and enhanced my skills in cardiac tissue engineering, along with presenting and coding skills.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Sommer is an incredibly thoughtful and organized professor who presents course content in a clear and accessible manner and encourages deep learning beyond just memorization by sharing relevant research papers and offering both high-level overviews and detailed explanations to contextualize concepts within a broader framework. I really appreciate that he shares his lecture slides and recordings, which not only support review after class but also allow students to revisit material they may have missed. Many of my teachers avoid sharing these resources, likely as a way to encourage attendance, but Dr. Sommer's lectures are so engaging and informative that students want to go to class, and being able to review content afterward only enhances the learning experience and helps me achieve a deeper understanding. I also enjoy that he incorporates a variety of learning modalities—coding, reading primary literature, exploring both historical context and detailed anatomical content—which keeps the material dynamic and intellectually stimulating. Although the use of pop quizzes would typically not seem favorable, I found the way he implements them very positive and successful in encouraging me to consistently review notes, while his flexibility in offering partial and extra credit shows his genuine commitment to student success and learning. Overall, Dr. Sommer is an amazing and thoughtful professor and his dedication to both student learning and well-being is evident in every aspect of his teaching.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Mechanotransduction is a novel field which I have never exposed myself into, so I did learnt a lot about this new field and some of the ideas that I never heard about. (Used to believe actin filaments is just generating forces, which is not incorrect, but it is never the whole picture of what actin can do to cells)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how important it is to contextualize cell-based mechanical measurements, and to ensure proper scaling is used.
2. I learned how generalizing mathematical models to specific cellular-scale processes can greatly impact the quality of the analysis.
3. I learned just how complicated it is to connect the biochemical pathways to the mechanical processes that dictate cell behavior.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Cell mechanics concepts, critical thinking through final project.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of new techniques used to study cell mechanics like active and passive rheology. I learned literature searching and grant writing skills for the final project. And I was introduced to interesting topics and considerations in mechanotransuction.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Knowledge: Cellular mechanics; underlying proteinaceous cytoskeleton; simple mechanical models to describe their mechanics; governing systems of mechanotransduction.
Methods: Invaluable in vitro techniques. 
Skills: Experimental design and scientific rigor.
Insights: Better comprehensive understanding of the living world. New perspective of how problems are approached across multiple fields.
Ways of thinking: Improved fundamental engineering approach. Gained appreciation for the academic field and how concepts may apply to my own research, both now and in the future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I hope Prof. Dr. Hoffman will have new courses we could join. He is a great professor. I literally fell in love with the field and widened to a high extent my view as a biomedical engineer in this intriguing field.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course itself is content-heavy, but Dr. Hoffman made it very straight-forward. I started to fall a bit behind starting from lecture 6-7 when the focus of the course shifts a bit to the G' and G'' calculations (but it really has nothing to do with the lecturing style!). It was just because I didn't take any cell mechanics class back in undergrad and this part is a bit math-heavy. I do like how each homework refers us back to the lecture slides to help us refresh. The exam is hard to be honest but I think it's a fair distribution of the concepts we learnt in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that there were always reading associated with the content that we learned in lectures. I liked when we transitioned to reviewing papers in the field and found it helpful to read them before class but then walk through them together. I also really liked all of the resources available to be successful in the class. The content was new for most people in the class so it was useful to have lots of readings and review questions to guide us. I also found the homeworks to be really helpful becuase they forced you to review the content each week while also learning some new things.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the most significant things I learned was how to draft actionable and relevant grant proposals. Working on a proposal for a project investigating biomechanics in collegiate softball pitchers, I gained experience in describing study designs, selecting appropriate equipment, and defining experimental protocols for capturing data across different populations. This process developed my understanding of how to frame research questions and justify methods in a way that aligns with both scientific rigor and real-world applications.Another key learning experience came from preparing and delivering presentations on sensors relevant to our proposals. These flash-style presentations emphasized concise communication of key information, which not only helped my peers understand and potentially integrate these tools into their own proposals but also strengthened my ability to synthesize and present technical material effectively. This collaborative approach enhanced the course's interactive and applied nature, as it allowed the class to explore a range of solutions and technologies together.Weekly literature assignments also played a large role in my learning by providing a foundation for understanding the background and context of our chosen topics. These assignments guided us through the process of conducting thorough literature reviews, which were essential for identifying gaps in existing knowledge and setting the stage for our grant proposals. Overall, the course structure—combining proposal writing, presentations, mathematical modeling, and literature analysis—provided a comprehensive learning experience that has prepared me to think critically and contribute meaningfully to scientific research.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I particularly enjoyed the opportunities to break out into small groups for focused discussions, such as debating different sides of a legal dispute involving child injuries or brainstorming how to measure biomechanical variables with limited equipment. These discussions encouraged critical thinking and collaboration, allowing me to explore diverse perspectives and develop creative solutions.I also appreciated working in groups to solve problems on whiteboards, which provided a real-time view of what others were working on and how they approached the same challenges. This collaborative environment allowed us to bring in skills from previous coursework, such as dynamics, and apply them in a hands-on way. The course’s format, which minimized traditional lectures, created space for interactive problem-solving and real-time questions, creating a dynamic and engaging learning environment. These elements were invaluable, and I would strongly recommend keeping them in future iterations of the course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course offers a natural progression from BME 302, making it an good choice for someone looking to deepen their understanding of biomechanics and related physical studies. While it can be math- and physics-heavy at times, particularly with whiteboarded problem-solving sessions, these challenges are balanced by exciting components such as sensor presentations and the opportunity to prepare R03 research grants or proposals based on real-world criteria.I would highly recommend this course to anyone considering a career in biomechanics, designing experiments/studies, or academia. It provides valuable, hands-on experience in research and proposal writing. It’s also a great choice for those seeking an upper-level BME elective that allows you to fully engage in class without the added stress of excessive outside work. The blend of intellectual rigor and practical application makes it a truly rewarding experience.

response_text: Dr. Farsiu fostered an extraordinary classroom environment, encouraging participation like no other professor in BME (besides Dr. Elizabeth Bucholz, who also excels at this). question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Systematic understanding of deep tissue optical imaging principles
I gained a solid understanding of how light propagates in biological tissues, including scattering, absorption, and various modeling techniques such as diffusion theory and the radiative transfer equation. This helps me evaluate the strengths and limitations of different imaging modalities.
2. Interdisciplinary principles of hybrid imaging (UOT and PAT)
I learned how optical and acoustic methods can be integrated, such as using ultrasound to modulate light (UOT) or using light to generate acoustic signals (PAT), which significantly enhances imaging depth and resolution. This interdisciplinary approach has broadened my research perspective.
3. Critical modeling and analytical skills
Through problem sets and paper discussions, I developed skills in modeling light transport in tissues and critically evaluating experimental setups. These analytical skills are essential for conducting and interpreting research in biomedical optics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The overall learning environment of this course was highly engaging and intellectually stimulating. Professor Yao’s teaching style—blending foundational theory with cutting-edge research—helped me not only understand the core principles but also appreciate the real-world relevance of deep tissue optical imaging.Two components of the course were especially beneficial:Well-structured slides and derivation walkthroughs: The clarity and logical flow of the lecture materials made it easier to follow complex concepts, and the detailed mathematical derivations supported deeper understanding during post-class reviews.
Comparative explanations and interdisciplinary insights: The instructor frequently compared different imaging modalities, which helped me form a broader, integrated view of the field.
I would strongly recommend keeping these elements in future iterations of the course and suggest continuing to incorporate research case studies to inspire students’ curiosity and engagement with real-world applications.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
I could think of two ways. First, the lectures were engaging. The slides were carefully curated and made learning the topics quite easy. Second, the instructor was passionate and engaged with teaching both during the class, where he tried to engage everyone for participation and impart the material in a careful and easy-to-understand way, thanks to his deep understanding and teaching skills, and after class, where he and the TAs were mostly responsive to questions.
The class recordings were invaluable to my learning process, allowing me to revisit and review course materials after each session—I strongly recommend continuing this practice. Regarding quizzes, I would suggest incorporating exercises that require debugging code implementations. Given the potential for hallucinations in LLM models, developing these practical debugging and code comprehension skills would be particularly beneficial for gaining a deeper understanding of correct implementation, especially with more involved requests.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Palmeri is a fantastic professor who encourages his students to ask questions and truly wants his students to learn and gain the most from taking the course. While the class was technically two lectures and one lab period a week I appreciated how there was flexibility in this schedule where lecture periods became lab/ work/office hour time with the TA's and professor when there was a particularly challenging lab assignment assigned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you start the labs early - sometimes it's easy to push off until later if your lab is later in the week, but it's best to use the time during lecture/in lab to ask questions. Its very easy to run into one small problem that can leave your code not functioning, and that can be pretty stressful if you are on a time crunch. Use Dr Palmeri! He is a great resource, and he is great at getting back to you quickly when you have an issue. At a certain point, if a code issue has caused you to stall and you just can't figure it out, it's usually worth it to just ask. It will save you a lot of time that would've otherwise just been wasted.

I found myself really clicking with some lectures, while other concepts I learned better by toying with the code and studying the lecture slides on my own time.
I found the homework assignments appropriately challenging. For most questions, I had to dedicate a fair amount of time to reviewing lecture material, researching online, and trying different approaches, but I never found them impossible or overly frustrating to complete. The group project topic my group selected was well outside of my knowledge base, but I found a niche to occupy and did find I learned a lot about a subject I was previously unfamiliar with (though I suspect the outcomes of this assignment depend strongly on the individual group members).
I also found Prof. You's AI policy well-articulated and constructive to the learning environment. I feel that the assignments were worded very well to encourage positive use of AI without sacrificing understanding or engagement with the content.

As an engineer who does mostly benchtop work, I don't often see how my work goes from lab to market, and this course taught me how that works and then some. I learned really useful information about intellectual property, patents, FDA regulations, the different arms of business (e.g. marketing, sales, human resources), what types of products are capable of turning into a business, and also what distinguishes MedTech from other types of business models.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the mix of lecture and workshop components, but I may also like to see them integrated with each other more. Otherwise, it is easy to sit back and watch the workshops without learning content in the same way. I liked the amount and type of class participation Dr. Chatterjee asks for, since it makes people pay attention, analyse the content they're learning critically, and keeps the class moving. Projects as the focus of the class was really nice to get practical skills for implementing the same topics we were learning in lecture, and office hours offered a great way to learn from them the best. Overall, I really liked how fast paced and efficient lectures were, and they allowed you to make the most of the class if you wanted to. Please give Dr. Chatterjee a teaching award for the work of art that this class is.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will learn a lot if you are interested, just go to office hours and ask questions about any details you don't understand because things will build on each other quick (and sometimes the details aren't fully explained in lecture). Technically there's no penalty for not doing this (the projects are graded a bit leniently), but if you're taking this course you're probably interested in it, and you will get so much more out of the course if you do. The more work you put into your projects early on and consistently, the more ambitious you can be when working on cutting edge topics, and you'll really just disappoint yourself (not your grade) if you end up procrastinating and missing out on making something cool with all the support they give you here.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is generally challenging. However, Prof. Rubinstein is one of the most famous polymer physics researcher and you will learn many useful concepts and methods for sure. Therefore, it is more than suitable for anyone who want to do research in fields related to polymer. My suggestion is to read the textbook before each lecture, then you can understand the materials better. You can also record any questions you have during reading the textbook and go to the lectures with these questions, as Prof. Rubinstein likes students to ask questions. For homework, going to office hours and recitations will be helpful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my favorite course that I completed this semester because of my personal development in the course.  First, the course content was very relevant to my interests, as well as many other peers in the class.  This is the only course offered at Duke that provides BME students to learn about the complexities of cancer and the biomedical therapeutic applications.  Dr. Misha provided a very in-depth explanation of cancer, and his professional experience offered a unique learning opportunity for me to develop ideas for my own research interests.   While cancer is complex, biomedical engineering is very applicable to the future of treating cancer, so the foundation set by Dr. Misha was beyond insightful.  Secondly, I appreciated the opportunity for students to create and present their own presentations that highlighted the diversity of biomedical engineering applications in cancer.  This aspect of the course benefitted me in two ways.  For one, I was able to learn a plethora of applications to cancer treatment including utilizing nanoparticles, bacterial therapy, chemotherapy, combinatory therapies, and more.  Secondly, Dr. Misha established a safe learning environment for us to all build our presentations skills in our field of interest.

response_text: I really appreciate courses that teach the content at a deeper level than is required to retain for homework and exams. I really liked how Dr. Misha taught lectures that were content heavy and went into a great deal of detail, but then asked more simple questions on the homework. This allows us to be exposed to the complex material for our research and graduate studies but not be overwhelmed with trying to memorize it all. I really enjoyed the course structure of 3 homeworks, no exams, and a presentation and final paper and believe this should all remain the same. I also enjoyed how the course had a very coherent structure in the order of which the topics were presented. I also thought the powerpoint slides were constructed very well and were very helpful when I returned to them after class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Over this semester, this class built my knowledge of stem cells, their uses in regenerative and clinical applications, biological versatility, and considerations from the ground up. We began establishing stem cell fundamentals early on, like self-renewal capacity, levels of potency, cell surface markers (e.g., SSEA3, SSEA4), and telomerase expression. Then we transitioned through various topics like the ethical considerations of harvesting and using stem cells, and why informed consent and current stem cell laws set the basis for ethical stem cell research. We also discussed several applications of using induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) in tissue/organs/cell regeneration, cancer treatment, and reversing aging.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned quite a bit about stem cells. Specifically, how they are used and derived, how they are maintained and differentiated, and what their benefits are.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of skills associated with reading scientific papers and learning/ thinking about the techniques talked about in more broad ways. Learning their methods and thinking how I could apply in different ways. i gained the skill of discussion in class on these type of topics, and I gained the skill of asking/ discussing hard questions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critically reading the papers while thinking about limitations.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to more effectively read and understand complex scientific journals. I learned about stem cells and how they are currently used in research for many different applications. I learned how to collaborate with classmates on group quizzes and during discussions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Knowledge of the current application of stem cells towards treatment of dieases, disease modeling, in addition to the precise development of stem cells for research previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me about stem cell biology and current research methods and clinical therapies that use stem cells. I learned about the properties and differences between embryonic and pluripotent stem cells and the advantages/disadvantages of using these cell types. I learned about modeling platforms for developmental research and drug/therapy discovery that utilize stem cells. Specifically, we discussed organoids, organ-on-a-chip, and tissue-engineered scaffolds. I also learned about cell-based therapies and the challenges and considerations associated with them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to critically evaluate scientific research studies and retain the most important information from dense peer-reviewed research articles. In terms of course content, I gained knowledge in many new fields. For example: 
1. Modern ways of biological in-vitro testing includes creating organoids and organ-on-a-chip models, which can be manipulated in many ways to fit the study appropriately. 
2. Stem cells come in many shapes and sizes, depending where their niche in the body exists. 
3. Ethical considerations are extremely important when it comes to designing a scientific paper; before taking any major steps, it is important to consider ethical issues.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1.The differences in types of stem cells (EC, iPSc) and the benefits and downsides of each.
2. Potential stem cell based systems including organs-on-a-chip and organoids and the upsides and limitations of each.
3. How seemingly small factors (TFs, ECM, density, stress/strain) can impact stem cell fate, and how this can used for the better application of stem cells in engineering in medicine.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned specific knowledge about stem cells, such as the difference between multipotent, totipotent, and pluripotent cells. I learned about stem cell related current technologies such as organ-on-a-chip, and I also developed skill in reading scientific articles quickly and efficiently.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Defining important terminology and historical context in the stem cell engineering and therapy field.
2. Understand the structure and applications of organoids, organ-on-a-chip devices, and microfluidic devices, and be able to compare and contrast their applicability and use.
3. Present a piece of scientific literature and be able to explain and defend limitations and points of future work.

3) Learned ways to compare the performance of deep neural network models with actual biological neuronal data to understand hierarchical processing in the brain and develop better artificial models.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be aware that this class will require a significant dedication of time outside of class because in addition to near-weekly homework, you will need to meet regularly with your project group, work on those three projects on your own, conduct clinician interviews, and shadow (including a long clearance process). If you aren't able to dedicate sufficient time to complete the course requirements well, I don't think you'll be able to get much out of the course. You should also be aware that the vast majority of the course content is applicable to medical device development in general, and not specific to surgical technologies or medical robotics (beyond a few lectures discussing appropriate applications of automation in medicine and the Da Vinci surgical robot).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
One of the most critical skills I developed in this course was the ability to digest information provided by clinicians in either a lecture room or operating environment. This skill is critical in developing an understanding of the problems currently faced in the medical field.
Another key insight I learned in this course is the approach required for pitches to investors for new medical technologies. Specifically, in project 2 I learned a lot about effective communication strategies to different investing parties when pitching a product.
Finally, I felt like I had very little insight into the grant proposal side of medtech prior to this course. Following the final project, I feel like I have started to understand the fundamentals of applying for grants as well as the development of technological significant and innovative research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Stem Cell Differentiation and Lineage Commitment: I learned how embryonic and induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) can be guided to differentiate into specific cell types through the manipulation of growth factors, signaling pathways, and extracellular matrices. This helped me understand how developmental biology principles are applied in vitro to create disease models or potential therapies.
2. Organoid and Organ-on-a-Chip Technology: Through analyzing recent literature, I developed an appreciation for how 3D culture systems and microfluidic platforms can mimic complex tissue structures and physiological environments. These models provide valuable insights into organ development, drug testing, and disease modeling.
3. Ethical and Translational Considerations: I gained insights into the ethical challenges involved in stem cell research, including issues related to embryonic stem cells, informed consent in biobanking, and the clinical translation of stem cell therapies. The discussions helped me think critically about balancing scientific progress with responsible conduct and societal impact.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to pay attention to specific methodology when reading academic papers as Dr. Musah often asked us to consider how we would design our own experiments to validate similar findings as those observed in the papers. I learned important characteristics of stem cell biology and how they are applied in reproductive healthcare, studies of aging, and tissue engineering. I learned important characteristics of presenting a paper, including identifying what knowledge the field possessed at the time of publication, the gap the authors were trying to address, and the importance of highlighting the authors' backgrounds and why they are well suited to study the topic at hand.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment of the stem cell class was collaborative and discussion-driven, which created a dynamic space for critical thinking and peer-to-peer learning. These components were particularly effective in fostering active participation and helping us build confidence in discussing cutting-edge stem cell research.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The high-level research articles made the class stimulating, as well as the discussion questions that students proposed at the end of each of their presentations. The quizzes also were the right level of difficulty, not too hard but not too easy.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made this class intellectually stimulating was its focus on cutting-edge research in stem cell biology and its real-world applications. Engaging with primary literature, especially recent manuscripts, encouraged us to think critically and stay current with ongoing advancements in the field. The discussions also pushed us to connect experimental design with broader translational goals, which was both challenging and rewarding.That said, the course could be even more intellectually stimulating by incorporating more guided analysis of key papers from the instructor’s perspective. While student-led presentations were helpful for peer learning, more structured input from the instructor—such as walking us through experimental reasoning, data interpretation, or clinical relevance—would have deepened our understanding. Integrating occasional guest lectures or case studies from ongoing research could also spark further curiosity and engagement.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class discussion portion of the class made it more intellectually stimulating. Rather than just consuming the content from the papers/class presentation, we were challenged to reflect and expand on the material presented to us.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is really great to improve your critical thinking skills in terms of research. You'll start thinking about how/why researchers do specific experiments or try and develop specific technology. If you have never taken classes where you read research papers or have a minimal bio background, this may be a slightly difficult course because I feel like it is very much oriented toward students who know biology and are already doing research and familiar with the research world.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say it's a fun class that's not too difficult but you still learn a lot. It also really pushes you to think about the frontiers of stem cell research and applications and have insightful discussions about the ethics and scientific possibilities surrounding them. However, be prepared to read a lot of dense literature to get the most out of the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! The class applies no pressure, which honestly helps you learn more as you are not cramming random information into your brain, but rather having discussions and learning through conversation. Stem cells is such a interesting field that no class is boring!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Anyone who wants to take this course will find it to be a valuable introduction to the field of stem cell biology, especially in the context of regenerative medicine and translational research. The course offers an engaging opportunity to analyze primary literature, participate in in-depth discussions, and build skills in scientific communication. The instructor and teaching assistant provide strong support, and the topics covered are timely and relevant to current advances in the field.However, it is important to note that the course is not structured around traditional lectures. Instead, it relies heavily on student-led presentations and frequent quizzes. While this format promotes active learning and peer engagement, it may feel less structured for those who would benefit from more guided instruction. Including more lecture-based sessions—particularly to highlight the instructor’s expert perspective—could enhance the overall learning experience and provide greater clarity on complex topics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class is very interesting and provides a good introduction/contextualization to the field of stem cell biology and some of its applications. It is not an introductory undergraduate course, it is a graduate course, so some of the burden will be on you as a student to familiarize yourself with topics that you don't know as you read through some of the papers. That being said the course design is such that if you put in the work you will be able to get the grade you want. The class discussions are engaging and fun and I would recommend taking the course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
One of the most critical skills I developed in this course was the ability to digest information provided by clinicians in either a lecture room or operating environment. This skill is critical in developing an understanding of the problems currently faced in the medical field.
Another key insight I learned in this course is the approach required for pitches to investors for new medical technologies. Specifically, in project 2 I learned a lot about effective communication strategies to different investing parties when pitching a product.
Finally, I felt like I had very little insight into the grant proposal side of medtech prior to this course. Following the final project, I feel like I have started to understand the fundamentals of applying for grants as well as the development of technological significant and innovative research.

I have also learned about the various funding opportunities and necessary litigation to take into account when building a device/ company in the space.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is less about robotics and more about developing products for the medical world. You learn more about IP and research grants than actual robotics, but it gives a great introduction to the medical world and current innovations that exist. The scope of the course is very broad, so it is hard to get anything out of it except a brief understanding of many topics. If you get stuck with a bad group for your projects, the semester will not be fun.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In ME-555-10 / BME-590-11: Advanced Topics with Professors Siobhan Oca and Brian Mann, I gained a deep understanding of how to approach complex, open-ended problems through both engineering analysis and creative design. First, I learned how to critically evaluate and synthesize research literature, a skill that sharpened my ability to identify knowledge gaps and propose meaningful research directions. Second, I developed stronger project management and experimental planning skills, particularly in the context of interdisciplinary biomedical engineering challenges. Lastly, I gained insight into translating theoretical models into practical solutions whether through simulations, device prototypes, or clinical contexts which helped bridge the gap between abstract concepts and real-world impact.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the midterm project presentation, literature review presentation (felt it should be earlier in semester), and final poster presentation were all useful to the class and projects. I also enjoyed the guest lecturer who came in to discuss the process of obtaining grants.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment in ME-555-10 / BME-590-11 was incredibly supportive and intellectually engaging. Professors Siobhan Oca and Brian Mann created a space that encouraged open discussion, curiosity, and critical thinking. Their feedback during project check-ins and presentations was both constructive and motivating, pushing us to refine our ideas and think more deeply. The flexibility of the course structure—especially the emphasis on student-driven research and hands-on exploration—allowed us to dive into topics we were genuinely passionate about. I would definitely keep the project-based approach and the opportunity to explore real-world problems in future years, as it made the learning experience both relevant and impactful.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

The open-ended nature of the projects encouraged us to think creatively, question assumptions, and dive deep into areas that genuinely interested us. The interdisciplinary discussions and personalized feedback from Professors Oca and Mann added depth and kept us intellectually engaged. To enhance this further, incorporating occasional guest lectures from industry or research leaders could offer broader perspectives and expose students to emerging trends and applications in the field.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to code in C++, how to build a programming project based on a state machine framework, and how to use various machines like oscilloscopes, function generators, and waveform generators. 
The most valuable skill I learned was how to read and create state machines. I will be applying this skill in my future job position, so I felt that this skill was very applicable to the real world and valuable 
I also enjoyed learning how to code in C++. I had experience in other coding languages, but this was my first time using C++. I felt that it really helped improve my problem solving skills and debugging abilities. Finally, using the machines in the lab gave me great hands-on experience for possible testing that I may do at my job.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Developed a lot of firmware based knowledge, C coding skills, and technical report implementation all through repetitive use of the version control system Git. I specifically learned how to successfully use pulse width modulation (PWM) controllers, analog-to-digital converters (ADCs), and Bluetooth services at a firmware level to complete a task. Learned to navigate Zephyr framework code and the available libraries to debug my code and implement my desired functionalities. Learned how to implement good version control practices to make my work trackable and show my methodology as work progressed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1.Matlab coding. I was new to engineering and used to be really bad at coding but I totally get trained during the labs.
2. The engineering (or electrical) aspects of neural systems. I was a neuroscience major and all my understanding for the AP and H-H model was on surface. I knew what they are but didn't know why they are like that. In this course I learnt to understand them in a more engineering way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The course provided an in-depth overview of neural engineering topics such as action potential generation, computational modeling, electrical stimulation, and ion flow dynamics.
Much of the start of the course was devoted to how the behavior of neural cell membranes is analogous to and can be modeled by RC circuits, with this model being expanded throughout the course. 
The next section of the course was heavily devoted to discussing ion flow dynamics and how ion concentration changes coincide with the firing of action potentials. 
The last section of the course provided an overview of the Hodgkin-Huxley experiments, with explanations of the associated models.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was very beneficial and informative. In this class, I learned the area connecting electrodynamics neurology. The beginning of the course focused in depth on fundamental topics such as dipoles and how electric fields interact. The second portion of the course moved in to how this was related to neurons and gave a great understanding to why ions really move in action potentials and what each step of the H-H models mean. We also learned how several neuron characteristics can be found from the movement of ions such as conduction velocity or signal strength. The last bit of the course also described different action potentials in different kinds of cells in the body, such as cardiomyocytes. Overall, i thought this was a great class and helped me get a much better understanding of how/why these systems work the way they do.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There were a few seminars that were more interactive, like the RCR training on science communication for non-experts and the seminar on data visualization that I enjoyed the most. I think seminars are most engaging and informative when they are interactive and allow for questions where we can learn from the speaker/student panels. Another course aspect I enjoyed was the lab presentations since it was very helpful to learn what everyone in our cohort is doing for their research. The change to have group presentations with everyone in the same lab presenting at once went really well and made it easy to learn what different labs are working on at Duke BME and see how everyone's personal interests relate to their lab's work. The optional survey for feedback worked well too since I was able to give useful and specific feedback to some presentations and then sometimes I just wanted to listen and ask questions and not have to worry about filling out the survey for every group.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Human-Centered Needs Finding in Clinical Environments:
I learned how to conduct needs-finding in healthcare settings by observing clinical workflows and interviewing stakeholders. This helped me develop skills in identifying unmet needs and framing them in a way that prioritizes both user and system constraints.2. Systems Thinking in Health Innovation:
The course taught me to map complex healthcare systems, including identifying stakeholders, causal relationships, and systemic challenges. This broadened my ability to think holistically about how healthcare technologies impact patients, providers, and institutions.3. Translating Observations into Potential Actionable Design Criteria:
I developed skills in synthesizing research findings into potential criteria for product development. I am looking forward to next semester where we will be balancing technical feasibility, user desirability, and regulatory considerations when brainstorming and refining potential solutions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about ideation, need assessment, and skills for filtering down lots of ideas to one that has the most potential.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: As a non-BME student studying Design & Technology Innovation, I found this course to be incredibly valuable for learning how to apply design thinking principles to the healthcare space. The focus on needs finding, stakeholder engagement, and systems thinking allowed me to bridge my background in design with the complexities of medical technology. The interdisciplinary nature of the course made it accessible to students from diverse fields, and the collaborative environment helped me gain insights from peers with varied expertise. If you’re interested in human-centered design in healthcare or want to explore innovation in clinical settings, this course is an excellent opportunity to develop those skills, even without a technical or biomedical background.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: As a non-BME student studying Design & Technology Innovation, I found this course to be incredibly valuable for learning how to apply design thinking principles to the healthcare space. The focus on needs finding, stakeholder engagement, and systems thinking allowed me to bridge my background in design with the complexities of medical technology. The interdisciplinary nature of the course made it accessible to students from diverse fields, and the collaborative environment helped me gain insights from peers with varied expertise. If you’re interested in human-centered design in healthcare or want to explore innovation in clinical settings, this course is an excellent opportunity to develop those skills, even without a technical or biomedical background.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Human-Centered Needs Finding in Clinical Environments:
I learned how to conduct needs-finding in healthcare settings by observing clinical workflows and interviewing stakeholders. This helped me develop skills in identifying unmet needs and framing them in a way that prioritizes both user and system constraints.2. Systems Thinking in Health Innovation:
The course taught me to map complex healthcare systems, including identifying stakeholders, causal relationships, and systemic challenges. This broadened my ability to think holistically about how healthcare technologies impact patients, providers, and institutions.3. Translating Observations into Potential Actionable Design Criteria:
I developed skills in synthesizing research findings into potential criteria for product development. I am looking forward to next semester where we will be balancing technical feasibility, user desirability, and regulatory considerations when brainstorming and refining potential solutions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about ideation, need assessment, and skills for filtering down lots of ideas to one that has the most potential.

response_text: I really enjoyed that fact that DH1,2,3 simulate the course of product development. response_text: I would have loved a dedicated lecture on human factors and usability. I picked up some of this through trial-and-error and team experimentation, but it would have been valuable to learn established frameworks or methods used in industry. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated all the class time devoted to working on our projects. It was sometimes difficult to meet as a whole team, so having that time most weeks to regroup was great. The weekly technical updates gave us a low-stress environment to get feedback and advice from the professors on our progress, and their guidance was crucial to our success. Additionally, we learned a ton from our meetings with industry experts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course has been one of my favorite experiences at Duke. The industry-specific learning I have gained from this course in unparalleled. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Knowledge: Fundamental immunobiology and relevant immune cell type of both the innate and adaptive immune system. Practical engineering and application knowledge regarding how these concepts are being applied in contemporary research literature.Methods, Skills: Fundamentals regarding methods of characterization, both in vitro and in vivo, through in-depth literature reviews of contemporary research articles, as well as how we can employ these methods in new contexts through writing our own, novel research proposalsInsights: Learning both immunobiology and contemporary immunoengineering applications gives rise to insight regarding what people have already done, where the field is heading, and current gaps in the literature that we could address as researchers.

course: BME-790-01 : ADV TOP FOR GRADS IN BME.BME-790-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned a lot about how the immune system responds to various perturbations, and how over-correction can lead to autoimmunity.
2. The immune system involves many interconnected components, and affecting one component will lead to downstream effects.
3. There are many ways to engineer the immune system, and many of them do not need to be complicated.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Ultimately, I believe that this class has been rather insightful through fruitful discussions with a class full of people who truly wanted to learn to be good mentors. There is never necessarily a clear answer to things when it comes to interacting with other humans, and there are always compound factors and nuances to consider, but the more time we spend thinking about, discussing, and reflecting on being good people, leaders, and mentors the better shot we have at being one. Also, having tangible outcomes, like a shared expectations document, that can help us later on is a great benefit of the course.

response_text:
Initially, I reviewed the knowledge of signal and system again with Dr. Yao. Then I learnt basic principles of several imaging modalities used in hospital right now, ranging from X-ray, CT, ultrasound, and MRI.
1. The way x-ray photons interact with tissues: photoelectric effect and Compton scatter.
2. Mathematical description of CT (Radon Transform and Sinogram).
3. The principles of PET material.

response_text:
1) PET/SPECT in general, some specific things would be positron decay and how PMTs are used to amplify PET signal.
2) Source of X-Ray photons, BR and CR, and X-Ray spectrum coverage
3) Importance of photoelectric effect vs Compton scattering contribution to contrast and radiation dosage.

response_text: I understand the definition, scope, and usage of linear elasticity better. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend this course to 1st year master's students or undergrads who are interested in med devices. I think this course offers a good crash course. I do not think that this course should be required if you have taken Design Health. This course is similar but much less in-depth because Design Health is 3 semesters.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be aware that this class will require a significant dedication of time outside of class because in addition to near-weekly homework, you will need to meet regularly with your project group, work on those three projects on your own, conduct clinician interviews, and shadow (including a long clearance process). If you aren't able to dedicate sufficient time to complete the course requirements well, I don't think you'll be able to get much out of the course. You should also be aware that the vast majority of the course content is applicable to medical device development in general, and not specific to surgical technologies or medical robotics (beyond a few lectures discussing appropriate applications of automation in medicine and the Da Vinci surgical robot).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a very high-level overview of surgical robotics and the research field. No experience gained on building/ programming/ implementing robotic devices.

-How to market and pitch a product idea and consider financial aspects for investors

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
One of the most critical skills I developed in this course was the ability to digest information provided by clinicians in either a lecture room or operating environment. This skill is critical in developing an understanding of the problems currently faced in the medical field.
Another key insight I learned in this course is the approach required for pitches to investors for new medical technologies. Specifically, in project 2 I learned a lot about effective communication strategies to different investing parties when pitching a product.
Finally, I felt like I had very little insight into the grant proposal side of medtech prior to this course. Following the final project, I feel like I have started to understand the fundamentals of applying for grants as well as the development of technological significant and innovative research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to identify problems in surgery through first-person interaction, listening to experts, and conducting a literature review. I learned how to prototype a medical device meant for a surgical application based on that identified problem. I have also learned about the various funding opportunities and necessary litigation to take into account when building a device/ company in the space.

response_text: This course taught me a lot about using engineering methodologies to solve complex medical issues.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In ME-555-10 / BME-590-11: Advanced Topics with Professors Siobhan Oca and Brian Mann, I gained a deep understanding of how to approach complex, open-ended problems through both engineering analysis and creative design. First, I learned how to critically evaluate and synthesize research literature, a skill that sharpened my ability to identify knowledge gaps and propose meaningful research directions. Second, I developed stronger project management and experimental planning skills, particularly in the context of interdisciplinary biomedical engineering challenges. Lastly, I gained insight into translating theoretical models into practical solutions whether through simulations, device prototypes, or clinical contexts which helped bridge the gap between abstract concepts and real-world impact.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment in ME-555-10 / BME-590-11 was incredibly supportive and intellectually engaging.
